tossups.question: A family of these animals that evolved hooves to adapt to a purely terrestrial life was Planocraniidae. While diving, these animals can recirculate blood through the body without passing through the lungs, since their heart has separate left and right aortae connected by the Foramen of Panizza. In these animals, the astragalus connects to the leg rather than to the ankle; that unusual crurotarsal joint allows their legs to be held vertically beneath the body for (*) "high walking". Members of this order are the closest living relatives to birds; the two groups are the only extant archosaurs. Two close members of this order are commonly distinguished by whether they have a U-shaped or V-shaped snout. For 10 points, name this order of reptiles with a namesake Nile species.
tossups.answer: crocodilians [or suchians; or pseudosuchians; or Crocodilia; or Suchia; or Pseudosuchia; accept alligators or crocodiles]
tossups.answer_formatted: crocodilians [or suchians; or pseudosuchians; or Crocodilia; or Suchia; or Pseudosuchia; accept alligators or crocodiles]

tossups.question: The argument that this philosophical position offers a "speculative opportunity" is advanced in a book attacking "correlationism" by Ray Brassier. This position is called the "uncanniest of guests" which is "at the door" at the start of another book, which claims its advent will shape the "history of the next two centuries". Friedrich Jacobi's ("YAH-koh-bee'z") critiques popularized the name of this position, which is the one most commonly ascribed to the socialist tract Catechism of a Revolutionist by Sergey Nechayev. In (*) The Will to Power, Nietzsche claims this position is the logical outcome of purely moral systems such as Christianity. Its literary advocates include Stavrogin from Demons and Bazarov ("buh-ZAH-roff") from Fathers and Sons. For 10 points, what position holds that existence and morality have no purpose?
tossups.answer: nihilism [or Nihilismus; accept Nihil Unbound]

tossups.question: This composer's Piano Concerto No. 1 quotes Maria! hilf doch mir ("MAH-ree-ah heelf dokh MEER"), a church song from Tyrol. Pearl Jam typically opens concerts by playing a solo piano piece by this composer titled "Metamorphosis Two". The second movement of this composer's Piano Concerto No. 2 begins with a duet between the soloist and a Native American flute. Orange Mountain Music has produced many works by this composer of the album Solo Piano, including his (*) Concerto Project. Works by Lucinda Childs and Christopher Knowles feature in an opera by this composer whose three sections, titled "Train," "Trial," and "Spaceship," are demarcated by intermezzi in which solfège syllables are chanted, called "knee plays". For 10 points, name this minimalist composer whose Portrait Trilogy includes Einstein on the Beach.
tossups.answer: Philip Glass

tossups.question: Philip K. Dick's novel The Transmigration of Timothy Archer fictionalizes an essay by this author which examines an Episcopal bishop who died in an Israeli desert, named James Pike. Another essay by this author states "I want to tell you the truth, and already I have told you about the wide rivers" and is titled in reference to a work by James Baldwin. This author meditates on the murder of actor Ramon Navarro in an essay which recalls visiting Linda Kasabian, a jailed member of the (*) Manson family. This author included "Notes of a Native Daughter" in the section "Seven Places of the Mind" which, along with "Lifestyles in the Golden Land," is part of an essay collection about California in the late 1960s. For 10 points, name this author of The White Album and Slouching Towards Bethlehem.
tossups.answer: Joan Didion (The second essay is "Notes of a Native Daughter.")
tossups.metadata: The second essay is "Notes of a Native Daughter."

tossups.question: Fifty years before the Salem witch trials, Mary Parsons and her husband were accused of witchcraft in this city. Land for this city was purchased from the Agawam tribe by William Pynchon, ancestor of author Thomas Pynchon. In a later event, Luke Day's message that his forces would be late in arriving to this city was intercepted by William Shepard. This city's Watershops Pond was dammed in 1777 on the order of Henry Knox to make way for its best-known (*) facility, which names the most popular Union Army rifle from the Civil War. After marching from Northampton, disgruntled indebted farmers attempted to capture that facility in this city during Shays' Rebellion. For 10 points, name this Massachusetts city home to a revolutionary-era armory, which shares its name with Illinois' capital.
tossups.answer: Springfield, Massachusetts [accept Springfield Armory]

tossups.question: This entity must be carried on the head and may not be touched with unwashed hands. Every night, this entity is carried to bed on a palanquin; at dawn, it's carried back and consulted for the day's guidance. In a wedding tradition, a bride and groom hold a scarf while walking around this entity four times. When this entity has become too worn, it is cremated while surrounded by people praising the Wonderful Teacher; thus, like a human, it receives proper last rites or (*) antam sanskar. The four laavan are done while circling it. A yak-hair fan called a chaur is waved over this entity, as it's considered royalty and held on a throne called a takht. This entity, which consists mostly of Punjabi hymns, was designated the eternal successor of Gobind Singh. For 10 points, name this current guru, the holy text of Sikhism.
tossups.answer: Guru Granth Sahib [or Adi Granth]

tossups.question: While disguised, Nikolai Muraviev ("MOOR-ah-v'yeff") witnessed these people auctioning off slaves near Palvan Gate and convinced British administrator James Abbott to meet their ruler. These people may derive their name from a ruler who reversed the policies of his predecessor Tokhta and let Italian merchants settle the Crimea, while serving as the longest-reigning Khan of the Golden Horde. Until the 19th century, these people dominated Western Khwarezm ("KHWAH-reh-zum") as rulers of the Khanate of (*) Khiva ("KHEE-vuh"). The country named for these people contains the historical land of the Karakalpaks ("kar-uh-KAHL-pahks") and the seat of the Timurid ("TIM-ur-id") dynasty, Samarkand. That country named for these people was led from its 1991 independence until 2016 by the autocrat Islam Karimov ("KAH-ree-moff"). For 10 points, what Turkic people name a country whose capital is Tashkent?
tossups.answer: Uzbeks [or O'zbeklar; accept Öz Beg Khan or Uzbeg Khan; accept Uzbekistan; prompt on Turks or Oghuz people]
tossups.answer_formatted: Uzbeks [or O'zbeklar; accept Öz Beg Khan or Uzbeg Khan; accept Uzbekistan; prompt on Turks or Oghuz people]

tossups.question: This country is the setting of a novel in which Vilma loses her job after the protagonist leaves his childhood home on Salaverry Avenue, titled A World for Julius. This country's Etiqueta Negra literary magazine was formerly edited by the author of the novel Lost City Radio, Daniel Alarcón. In another novel from this country, an author writes a story in which a crowd gathers to hear Crisanto's music but dies an earthquake, since that author has gone insane and begun (*) killing off the characters he created for his employer Genaro ("heh-NAH-roh") Junior. The two narratives of that novel from this country follow Marito's affair with the title divorced relative and the radionovelas of Pedro Camacho. For 10 points, name this home country of the author of Aunt Julia and the Scriptwriter, Mario Vargas Llosa ("YOH-sah").
tossups.answer: Perú [or Republic of Perú, or República del Perú] (A World for Julius is by Alfredo Bryce.)
tossups.metadata: A World for Julius is by Alfredo Bryce.

tossups.question: Variety of this process which are "constitutive in the formation of a new identity" or forms of "humiliated silence" are among seven types of it distinguished by Paul Connerton. Tests for the "directed" form of this process present subjects with TBR items. An equation usually named for this process is often simplified as (read slowly) "R equals e to the negative power of t over s". Endel Tulving primed subjects with synonyms and homonyms to test the hypothesis that this process occurs when access to traces is (*) blocked, and is thus "cue-dependent". Varieties of this process caused by transience are modeled on a curve named for it by Hermann Ebbinghaus. The "tip-of-the-tongue" phenomenon is an example of this process caused by retrieval failure. For 10 points, name this process caused by amnesia.
tossups.answer: forgetting [accept retrieval failure before "retrieval"; accept partial recall or retention failure; accept weakening memory or memory deterioration or memory loss or memory erasure; prompt on memory or retrieval or recall or erasure; do not accept or prompt on "remembering" or "retention"]
tossups.answer_formatted: forgetting [accept retrieval failure before "retrieval; accept partial recall or retention failure; accept weakening memory or memory deterioration or memory loss or memory erasure; prompt on memory or retrieval or recall or erasure; do not accept or prompt on "remembering" or "retention"]

tossups.question: A work in this medium made with automobile lacquer depicts a nude woman extending her arms, each of which are attached to balls and chains. Tina Modotti, who photographed many works in this medium, holds a bandolier in one titled In the Arsenal. The "embrace and mixing of races" in the era before  "bourgeois democratic revolution" is depicted in a work in this medium housed in an eight-sided building. Works in this medium include The New Democracy and one found in a (*) "Polyforum Cultural" titled The March of Humanity. A statue of Jupiter holding a thunderbolt appears at left in a work in this medium that was destroyed by Nelson Rockefeller because it contained a portrait of Lenin. For 10 points, Man at the Crossroads is in what medium, popular among such Mexican artists as Diego Rivera?
tossups.answer: Mexican murals [or murallas]

tossups.question: Hydrozirconation of olefins always gives the terminal product since one of these reactions occurs rapidly to any internal product. One class of these reactions can occur to complexes with 16 or fewer electrons where a metal bonds to an alkyl group with a hydrogen on the beta carbon. A redox example of these reactions is the third and final step in the mechanism for (*) palladium-catalyzed cross-coupling reactions. When synthesizing carboxylic acid derivatives via nucleophilic attack on the carbonyl, this kind of reaction decomposes the tetrahedral intermediate. Like the analogous substitutions, the unimolecular mechanism for these reactions involves a carbocation. For 10 points, name these reactions in which two substituents are removed from an organic compound, the opposite of an addition.
tossups.answer: elimination reactions [accept beta-hydride elimination or reductive elimination]

tossups.question: This film's director appreciated Don Percival's voice so much that his voice was used for the cabaret-esque song "One More Kiss, Dear". The question "Do you like our owl?" is posed at the beginning of a track from this movie by a character who is subsequently asked a question about a butterfly "killing jar". In the final track from this film's soundtrack, a villain played by Rutger Hauer recalls viewing (*) C-beams glitter in the dark near Tannhauser Gate. That track is this film's "Tears in the Rain" monologue. The second song from this film's soundtrack, "Blush Response," is an alternate name for the Voight-Kampff test performed on the replicant Rachel. Harrison Ford plays Rick Deckard in, for 10 points, what Ridley Scott movie inspired by Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?
tossups.answer: Blade Runner [do not prompt on or accept "Blade Runner: 2049"]
tossups.answer_formatted: Blade Runner [do not prompt on or accept "Blade Runner: 2049"]

tossups.question: These things can be identified by a "holistically-nested" algorithm developed by Xie and Tu. The maximum strength of these things is calculated by rotating a single kernel mask through all 8 compass directions in the Kirsch operator. A Gaussian filter removes noise and hysteresis "tracks" these things in an algorithm developed by John Canny whose second step computes an intensity gradient. These things can be constructed without doing any floating-point calculations using (*) Bresenham's algorithm. The top-left rule considers a pixel to be rasterized if its center lies on a "top" or "left" one of these things. Anti-aliasing reduces "jaggedness" in, for 10 points, what geometric constructs, along which color values are interpolated between two vertices?
tossups.answer: edges [accept lines or line segments; prompt on features]

tossups.question: Objects made of this material unearthed at Kapona na Dari that were created near New Britain suggest that Lapita expansion was driven by trade of this material. Shark's teeth, frigate bird bones, or this material were used to create the Rongorongo glyphs. The thickness of bands of absorbed water are used to date artifacts made of this material using its namesake "hydration dating". The Sierra de las Navajas ("nah-VAH-has") was where an unusually (*) green form of this material was mined by the Teotihuacan ("tay-oh-tee-WAH-kan") civilization. According to Bernal Díaz del Castillo ("DEE-ahs del kahs-TEE-yoh"), microscopically-sharp blades made of this material could decapitate horses with a single swing. This material was often painted red on sacrificial knives known as tecpatl ("tek-PAH-tl"). The Aztecs made many weapons with, for 10 points, what black volcanic glass?
tossups.answer: obsidian [or itztli; prompt on volcanic glass before mentioned; prompt on stone or equivalents]
tossups.answer_formatted: obsidian [or itztli; prompt on volcanic glass before mentioned; prompt on stone or equivalents]

tossups.question: Description acceptable. Hundreds of thousands of pick-up locations complementing this service have been built by the Dutch startup Azimo, one of many firms which have partially outmoded KTT methods of doing it. A substantial reduction in poverty in Kenya has been credited to a tool that provides this service named M-Pesa. A strategic partnership to enable this service in the U.S. has been forged by Wal-Mart with Ria and another company providing this service, (*) Xoom, which was acquired in 2015 by a firm whose CEO is Peter Schulman. In many countries, the development of apps for this service has reduced immigrants' reliance on Western Union for sending remittances. For 10 points, identify this service provided by such apps as Zelle and Venmo.
tossups.answer: money transfer [accept answers which indicate logical equivalents of the ability to send money or send mobile payments; accept answers which refer to sending remittances before "remittances"; accept peer-to-peer payment; prompt on transfer; prompt on SMS or messaging; prompt on banking]
tossups.answer_formatted: money transfer [accept answers which indicate logical equivalents of the ability to send money or send mobile payments; accept answers which refer to sending remittances before "remittances; accept peer-to-peer payment; prompt on transfer; prompt on SMS or messaging; prompt on banking]
acceptable: answers which indicate logical equivalents of the ability to send money
answers which refer to sending remittances

tossups.question: A namesake mosque in Mecca is at the site of Muhammad's conversion of some of these figures, as recounted in a namesake surah, in which one of these figures admits to having believed that no one ever lied against God. A captured one of these figures named al-Harith led a war against one of their kings. Like a later-created group, these figures are considered to possess the "trust" of God in the form of free will. Anyone who claimed to have (*) seen one of these figures was barred from testifying since, except to prophets, they're invisible. Rather than a fallen angel, Iblis is now generally considered one of these figures. Reciting the Throne Verse is often used in Islamic exorcisms to cure possession by them. God used smokeless fire to create, for 10 points, what magical Islamic spirits?
tossups.answer: jinni [accept genies]

tossups.question: A passage of this novel claims it would be impossible to understand a woman's matchmaking by following her "pony-phaetons" even if "a telescope...swept the parishes of Tipton and Freshitt". A doctor in this novel seeks to understand romance by studying "primitive tissue" after his disastrous affair with Madame Laure. After becoming destitute by funding his naturalist hobbies through gambling, a vicar in this novel inherits (*) Lowick Parsonage after its proprietor dies. Because he cannot read German, a scholar in this novel struggles to complete his Key to All Mythologies. In this novel, the medical reformer Tertius Lydgate struggles financially after marrying Rosamond Vincy. Edward Causabon and Dorothea Brooke also marry in, for 10 points, what "study of provincial life" by George Eliot?
tossups.answer: Middlemarch, A Study of Provincial Life
acceptable: Middlemarch, A Study of Provincial Life
Middlemarch, A Study of Provincial Life

tossups.question: A column in this city that reads "and now, for his iniquitous betrayal / this has been placed to frighten others" was targeted at a rebel leader who fled this city after a falling mortar killed his standard bearer. In 1606, Pope Paul V placed the last of many Papal interdicts against this city for trying priests in secular courts. This city attempted to quell worship of St. Titus in its colony of Candia. Citizens would report suspicious activity to this city's (*) Council of Ten by placing messages in the mouths of lion statues. This city's glassmakers were confined on pain of death to the island of Murano. Soldiers were forced to sack Zadar in order to pay this city for a fleet it built during the Fourth Crusade. For 10 points, name this Italian mercantile city-state with many canals.
tossups.answer: Most Serene Republic of Venice [or Serenissima Repubblica di Venezia]
tossups.answer_formatted: Most Serene Republic of Venice [or Serenissima Repubblica di Venezia]

tossups.question: In a poem titled for two of these animals, the speaker experiences "wild musky scents on my body after long nights of dreaming". The title poem of a 1983 collection mentions that these animals "were maps drawn of blood" and "were bodies of sand". In a poem about one of these animals, the speaker flies "into the red eye, the cauldron of morning" and notes a "stasis in darkness". The current U.S. Poet Laureate, (*) Joy Harjo, wrote a collection titled for these animals, another of which is the subject of Sylvia Plath's poem "Ariel". A "little" one of these animals "asks if there is some mistake" in a poem in which one of these animals "must think it queer to stop without a farmhouse near". The speaker of Robert Frost's "Stopping By Woods on a Snowy Evening" rides, for 10 points, what animal?
tossups.answer: horse [or obvious equivalents like pony or stallion; accept Equus ferus caballus; accept "Two Horses" or She Had Some Horses; prompt on equine or equus]
tossups.answer_formatted: horse [or obvious equivalents like pony or stallion; accept Equus ferus caballus; accept Two Horses or She Had Some Horses; prompt on equine or equus]

tossups.question: In 2015, a team led by Su-Yang Xu ("shoo") et al. made the first observation of one variety of these particles in crystals with broken inversion symmetry. The Nelson-Ninomiya theorem asserts that the typical method of discretizing these particles on a chiral lattice leads to doubling the number of fields. Weyl ("vile") semimetals host unusual examples of these particles, whose fields obey a canonical anti-commutation relation. An equation of motion for these particles can be expressed in Feynman slash notation to represent the (*) gamma matrices. Applying the exchange operator flips the sign of a wavefunction of two of these particles. Two identical ones cannot occupy the same quantum state according to the Pauli exclusion principle. For 10 points, name these particles with half-integer spin.
tossups.answer: fermions [accept Weyl fermions or Majorana fermions; prompt on spin 1/2 particles or particles with half-integer spin; prompt on electrons by saying "we want a more general answer"]
tossups.answer_formatted: fermions [accept Weyl fermions or Majorana fermions; prompt on spin 1/2 particles or particles with half-integer spin; prompt on electrons by saying "we want a more general answer]
promptable: electrons by saying "we want a more general answer

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, name these modern German-language authors of philosophical novels:
answers: W. G. Sebald [or Winfried Georg Sebald; or Max Sebald]
parts: The title character of this Swiss-German author's coming-of-age novel Siddharta pursues spiritual enlightenment throughout his journey to meet Gautama Buddha.
Immanuel Kant and Henri Bergson's philosophies of time are interwoven throughout this German emigrant author's novels, such as Austerlitz and The Rings of Saturn.

This author described his philosophy of the inwardly-free Anarch in his novel Eumeswil ("OY-mesh-vil"), which is set in a post-apocalyptic Morocco ruled by a tyrant named The Condor. His memoir of World War II is titled Storm and Steel.
answers_formatted: W. G. Sebald [or Winfried Georg Sebald; or Max Sebald]

bonuses.leadin: This artist's late black-and-white depictions of Biblical scenes include The Vision of Death and The Confusion of Tongues. For 10 points each:
answers: Gustave Doré (Those are from his Divine Comedy series.)
Eugène Delacroix (Those paintings are The Barque of Dante and The Women of Algiers.)
parts: Name this 19th century illustrator whose best-known series includes scenes of a couple gazing into the Empyrean and Virgil watching a man rise from a grave.

Like his contemporary Doré, this artist drew on the Divine Comedy for his first major work, in which Dante stands on a boat and looks over his shoulder at a burning city. In another of his paintings, a black servant at right attends to three women in a harem.
This later French artist was inspired by Dante to sculpt his masterpiece The Gates of Hell.
metadata: Those are from his Divine Comedy series.
Those paintings are The Barque of Dante and The Women of Algiers.

bonuses.leadin: The oldest known ekphrasis is the description of an elaborate shield made for this hero, who earlier refuses to lead his troops into battle after he's forced to give Briseis to Agamemnon. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Greek hero who's killed during the Trojan War when an arrow shot by Paris hits his heel.
Achilles commands these elite warriors. Their name comes from the Greek for "ant" because Zeus either seduced their ancestor Eurymedousa in the form of an ant or turned them from ants into men.
In some accounts, this island was colonized by the ants that became the Myrmidons, and Zeus created the Myrmidons as a gift to its king Aeacus ("EE-uh-kus").

bonuses.leadin: In recent years, production of this crop has been stifled by the Swollen Shoot Virus. For 10 points each:
answers: cocoa bean [or cacao bean; accept chocolate]
Thomas Richard Harkin or Eliot Lance Engel [accept Harkin-Engel Protocol]
parts: The English Cadbury brothers exploited African labor to harvest what crop? The Ivory Coast is currently the world's largest exporter of this crop.

Ironically, William Cadbury hired Dr. Joseph Burtt to investigate whether this empire was using slaves to harvest cocoa. The UNITA and MPLA parties fought for the independence of one of this country's colonies in the 1960s.
A 2000 BBC documentary sparked these two American congressman to author a protocol that sought to end the use of child labor in harvesting cocoa in West Africa. Name either.
answers_formatted: Thomas Richard Harkin or Eliot Lance Engel [accept Harkin-Engel Protocol]
acceptable: Thomas Richard Harkin or Eliot Lance Engel
Thomas Richard Harkin or Eliot Lance Engel

bonuses.leadin: A polymer of this compound was the first-discovered conducting polymer. For 10 points each:
answers: copper [or Cu] (The second sentence refers to Gilman reagents.)
parts: Name this compound, a commercial precursor to indigo dye. Louis Hammett developed his acidity function from experiments on derivatives of this compound.
Aniline consists of an amine substituent bonded to this simple hexagonal aromatic molecule.

The Sandmeyer reaction can convert aniline into an aryl halide by adding nitrous acid and a halide salt of this transition metal. A class of organometallic reagents that contains this element and lithium can perform 1,4 addition reactions.
metadata: The second sentence refers to Gilman reagents.

bonuses.leadin: A set of shipwrecks off the coast of this island are nicknamed the "The Three C's", and are now popular scuba destinations. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this island. Cold fresh water has helped preserve the wrecks of over 25 ships which sank on its reefs, most near the Rock of Ages light.
Isle Royale is located in this lake, famed for "not giving up its dead". The main American port on this largest Great Lake is Duluth, Minnesota.

The most famous ship to have sunk in Lake Superior is this freighter which went down in 1975. A Newsweek article titled "The Cruelest Month" inspired Gordon Lightfoot to write a song about the "Wreck of" this ship.

bonuses.leadin: This novella's protagonist has recurring dreams of a strange cat with the head of Boris Ismailov ("bah-REES ees-MY-loff"). For 10 points each:
answers: Lady Macbeth of the Mtsensk District [or Ledi Makbet Mtsenskovo uyezda]
parts: Name this novella whose title character is accused of having "cupids" by her husband Zinovy, whom she then strangles and buries in a cellar.
Nikolai Leskov's Lady Macbeth of the Mtsensk District was published in Epoch, a magazine edited by this author of The Brothers Karamazov.

Leskov also wrote many short works called zapiski, a word usually translated as either "notes" or as this English term. For example, Ivan Turgenev's set of zapiski relating a hunter's travels with Yermolay are usually titled for this term in English.
answers_formatted: Lady Macbeth of the Mtsensk District [or Ledi Makbet Mtsenskovo uyezda]
acceptable: Lady Macbeth of the Mtsensk District
Lady Macbeth of the Mtsensk District

bonuses.leadin: In an absurdist play by this author, Dr. Bero kidnaps and tortures his own father to learn the secrets of the cult of As. For 10 points each:
answers: Wole Soyinka [accept Akinwande Oluwole Babatunde Soyinka] (The other play is Death and the King's Horsemen.)
J. P. Clark [or John Pepper Clark-Bekederemo]
parts: Name this author of Madmen and Specialists who wrote another play in which a planned ritual suicide is interrupted by the colonial officer Simon Pilkings, who declares it illegal.
Soyinka is a Nobel Laureate from this African country, also home to Chinua Achebe.

Like Soyinka, this author of The Song of the Goat was one of several Nigerian playwrights active in Ibadan's Mbari Club in the 1960s. This author wrote a poem titled "Ibadan," as well as several poetic adaptations of Ijaw legends.
metadata: The other play is Death and the King's Horsemen.

bonuses.leadin: A politician from this country wrote the pamphlet The Future of Palestine. For 10 points each:
answers: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland [accept Great Britain; accept U.K.]
parts: Name this country, whose foreign secretary issued a namesake 1917 declaration supporting a Jewish homeland in Palestine.

Before Balfour, Joseph Chamberlain worked with this man to establish a temporary Jewish homeland in the Uganda Scheme. This founder of Zionism discussed the "Jewish Question" in his 1895 pamphlet Der Judenstaat ("dare YOO-den-shtaht").

Many English Zionists followed this theology, which argues that allowing the Jews to return to Palestine will lead the way for the Second Coming. John Nelson Darby popularized this theology in the U.K.
answers_formatted: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland [accept Great Britain; accept U.K.]
acceptable: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

bonuses.leadin: The stability of these devices can be limited in the Dick effect. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these devices which may use a group of lasers to create a "fountain" effect. The NIST-F1 is one of these devices, which rely on hyperfine transitions in cold atoms.
Atomic clocks are more precise than previous clocks using a crystal oscillator made from this piezoelectric mineral, which has a value of 7 on the Mohs hardness scale.

JILA at the University of Colorado-Boulder is home to a very precise clock that uses strontium atoms in one of these systems. These systems consist of interfering laser beams, which trap atoms in minima of a periodic potential.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer the following about musical settings of Walt Whitman's poems:
answers: A Sea Symphony [accept Symphony No. 1 by Ralph Vaughan Williams; prompt on Symphony No. 1 by asking "whose symphony?"; do not accept or prompt on "Sea"]
parts: This composer incorporated Whitman's "When Lilacs Last in the Dooryard Bloom'd" into his tone poem Ode to Death, which he wrote three years after The Planets.
A boy sings "I have treasured every note" after hearing a bird cry in this composer's piece Sea Drift. This British composer wrote the opera A Village Romeo and Juliet.

A baritone sings "Away, O Soul!" in the "Explorers" movement of this orchestral piece, whose second movement sets Whitman's "On the Beach at Night Alone". This piece begins with a brass fanfare, followed by a chorus singing "Behold!"
answers_formatted: A Sea Symphony [accept Symphony No. 1 by Ralph Vaughan Williams; prompt on Symphony No. 1 by asking "whose symphony?; do not accept or prompt on "Sea"]
acceptable: Symphony No. 1 by Ralph Vaughan Williams

bonuses.leadin: In the essay "Famine, Affluence, and Morality," this philosopher argues that wealthy people are morally obliged much more to donate to humanitarian causes than they do. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this author of Practical Ethics whose other work popularized the term "speciesism".
Many of Singer's arguments draw on this philosophy developed by Jeremy Bentham, which is often paraphrased as "the greatest good for the greatest number".

Singer gave a TED Talk in favor of this philosophical movement, which proposes to study ways to benefit others as much as possible and act on them. William McCaskill's book Doing Good Better is a primer on this movement.

bonuses.leadin: This man added the color gold, representing heaven, to The Wordless Book. For 10 points each:
answers: Dwight Lyman Moody [accept Moody Bible Institute]
China [or Zhongguo; accept China Inland Mission; accept Qing dynasty, Great Qing, or Da Qing; accept People's Republic of China or Zhonghua Renmin Gongheguo]

Scotland [accept Kingdom of Scotland; prompt on United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland, United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland, the UK, or Great Britain; do not accept or prompt on "England"]
parts: Name this man who evangelized to Union troops as president of the Chicago YMCA. He names a Bible Institute in Chicago's North Side.

The main use of Moody's version of The Wordless Book was missionary work in this country, which he promoted after meeting Hudson Taylor, founder of its Inland Mission. The three-self formula was developed for missions to it and names its Three-Self Patriotic Movement.
While touring this country with Ira Sankey, Moody laid the foundation for its Carrubbers Christian Centre. John Knox founded Presbyterianism in this country.
answers_formatted: China [or Zhongguo; accept China Inland Mission; accept Qing dynasty, Great Qing, or Da Qing; accept People's Republic of China or Zhonghua Renmin Gongheguo]

Scotland [accept Kingdom of Scotland; prompt on United Kingdom of Great Britain or Northern Ireland, United Kingdom of Great Britain or Ireland, the UK, or Great Britain; do not accept or prompt on "England"]
promptable: Northern Ireland, United Kingdom of Great Britain

bonuses.leadin: This dynasty's general Nasr al-Din participated in its invasion of Burma. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this dynasty. Iron-tipped stakes that were only revealed during low tide prevented this dynasty's navy from retreating at the Second Battle of Bạch Đằng ("bek dung").
This present-day country's Trần dynasty fended off two invasions from the Yuan dynasty. The Trung Sisters had earlier rebelled against the Han dynasty in this country.

During the Lam Son uprising, this Vietnamese leader successfully rebelled against the Ming dynasty. This leader legendarily possessed the sword "Heaven's Will," allowing him to change his height at will.

bonuses.leadin: The formation of these structures is regulated by the zone of polarizing activity and the apical ectodermal ridge. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these structures, which develop from buds in the lateral plate mesoderm.

A classic example of this process during embryonic development is the elimination of webbing between the digits in humans. Executioner caspases degrade intracellular proteins in this process of controlled cell death.
Limb development is regulated by a family of growth factors named for stimulating these connective tissue cells. These cells produce collagen and other components of the extracellular matrix.

bonuses.leadin: Richard Nixon supposedly told Richard Helms to "make the economy scream" in response to the election of this leader. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this leader. Orlando Letelier, this leader's ambassador to the U.S., tried to negotiate the nationalization of his country's copper mines.

Prior to Allende's ("AH-yen-DAYS") election, the U.S. sponsored a program to send Chileans to learn at this university from Milton Friedman. Sergio de Castro was among the economists known as this school's "Boys".
Sergio de Castro was one of the main authors of this gigantic economics manual that advocated massive spending cuts in order for Chile to achieve total economic freedom.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer the following about Erving Goffman's theories of calculated social interaction:
parts: In Strategic Interaction, Goffman applies this economist's game theoretic approaches to sociology. This economist's book The Strategy of Conflict applies that same approach to nuclear weapons and war.
Another article by Goffman coins the term for this practice of taking calculated action to alter one's social identity, and calls it a key "ritual element" of interaction.
Goffman's Presentation of Self in Everyday Life likens social interactions to performances in one of these places, and is thus called "dramaturgical analysis".

bonuses.leadin: Ezra Pound's poem "In a Station of the Metro" is sometimes considered one of these poems, even though it has 19 syllables instead of 17. For 10 points each:
answers: haiku [or hokku; accept The Essential Haiku]
parts: Name these poems. Robert Hass's collection of "essential" examples of them includes works by Bashō, Buson, and Issa.

This poet invented the "American Sentence," a single line of 17 syllables. He ended a translation of Bashō's frog haiku with the word "Kerplunk!" and incorporated Buddhist themes into his "Sunflower Sutra".
This other American poet won the 1925 Pulitzer Prize for a collection of 24 haiku and took inspiration from Japan to write the collection Pictures of the Floating World.

bonuses.leadin: The crankshaft translates the reciprocal motion of these objects into rotation. For 10 points each:
answers: quasistatic [do not accept or prompt on partial answers]
O-rings [accept toric joints, prompt on packings or gaskets]
parts: Name these cylindrical objects, which are made to periodically move up and down by the ignition of fuel in an internal combustion engine.

The compression of a gas by a piston subject to friction is the classic example of a process that is not reversible, but has this property, meaning the change occurs slowly enough to preserve thermodynamic equilibrium.
Pistons in hydraulic and pneumatic systems may be fitted with these circular objects, which seal off the chamber from the outside. They can be linked to a U-cup to strengthen the seal.
answers_formatted: quasistatic [do not accept or prompt on "partial answers"]

bonuses.leadin: This musician's 160 recordings for Columbia Records include "Downhearted Blues" and "Gulf Coast Blues". For 10 points each:
answers: "Ma" Rainey [accept Gertrude Pridgett] (The unnamed song is "Black Bottom.")
parts: Name this "Empress of the Blues" who recorded a 1925 rendition of W.C. Handy's "St. Louis Blues". She was known for her deep contralto voice.
Smith collaborated with this jazz trumpeter on her recording of "St. Louis Blues". This New Orleans-born musician was nicknamed "Satchmo".

This other jazz singer recorded "Jelly Bean Blues" with Armstrong. Bessie Smith was mentored by this so-called "Mother of the Blues," whose other recordings include one of "See See Rider Blues" and one of a raucous rural African-American dance.
